review_title: "University of Birmingham: A World-Class Institution of Learning, Research, and Community Engagement"
pros: Reputation: The University of Birmingham is a well-regarded institution both in the UK and internationally. It is a member of the prestigious Russell Group of UK universities, known for their focus on research and high academic standards. Diverse Programmes: The University offers a wide range of undergraduate and postgraduate programmes, ensuring a broad array of study options for students. Research Opportunities: As a research-intensive university, students have access to various research opportunities and resources. Campus and Facilities: The University boasts a beautiful campus with state-of-the-art facilities for learning, research, sports, and leisure. Location: Birmingham is a vibrant, multicultural city with a lot to offer in terms of culture, entertainment, and job opportunities.
cons: Competitiveness: Due to its high reputation, competition for places, particularly in popular courses, can be high. Cost: Tuition and cost of living can be high, particularly for international students. Size: With a large student population, some students may feel overwhelmed or find it harder to establish personal connections. Urban Campus: While some enjoy the energy of a city-based campus, others may prefer a more traditional or rural university setting. Course Rigor: Some students might find the academic rigor and workload demanding, which requires good time management and study skills.

pros: Lovely environment to work, with a real community feel.

pros: The University of Birmingham Coding Skills Bootcamp is an intensive program designed to help individuals acquire new coding skills and advance their careers in the technology industry. This 16-week program offers a comprehensive curriculum, expert instructors, and practical experience to provide participants with the tools they need to succeed. One of the strengths of this bootcamp is its focus on hands-on learning. Participants work on real-world projects throughout the program, allowing them to apply the coding skills they learn in a practical context. This approach can help participants build a portfolio of work that they can use to showcase their skills to potential employers. In addition, the University of Birmingham Coding Skills Bootcamp offers a supportive learning environment. Instructors and mentors are available to help participants navigate the program and answer questions. The bootcamp also provides networking opportunities, allowing participants to connect with other individuals in the tech industry and potentially find job opportunities.
cons: Overall, the University of Birmingham Coding Skills Bootcamp is an excellent program that provides a comprehensive and supportive learning environment for individuals looking to advance their coding skills and careers in the tech industry.

review_title: Don't work here in Psychology. Go elsewhere- any of the big London Universities, or Manchester if you can.
pros: Raw research tools (e.g., MRI machines), good students, nice colleagues, pretty campus.
cons: I've been here for years. It was the worst job I've ever had. I've worked in four countries, and this was the worst managed university I've ever seen. Let's break things down: 1. There is no contingency planning. Hell, there's no PLANNING. You will be asked to do a massive task with a day's notice, with no prior discussion. There will be people who will be off sick, and you'll be asked to step in to a brand new role for a LONG time with no changes to your other duties. 2. Rewards are unconnected to actual tasks of the role. Be the best teacher you can be, winning awards and students emailing upper management, be the best researcher and publish in Nature, and you will not be promoted. Instead, someone with a lower research profile than you will because they agreed to shoot their weekends in the face by taking a role no one wants. If you win a grant, it will be not enough because it's not big enough, or worse, it's not the right kind. 3. You WILL work on the weekends. See planning. 4. Teaching is weird compared to other universities. In most of the other russell group universities, you don't mark students at the first and second year level. Here, ALL marking must be done by people with PhDs- even if outside of the subject. I taught cognition, and I had a neurologist marking my students. Marking is heavy in load, and has unrealistic requirements or the time. The teaching support is non-existent. Teaching assistants are basically sparse and have no duties, and are deeply underpaid with weird limits. You are asked to make massive changes to teaching within days because they're so disorganised. 5. If you complain about something, management will do EVERYTHING they can to make it a problem that is because of YOU. Not because of situation or the lack of support. 6. Research. Your research time is NOT protected time. You will not be given time to research anything even if your grant has given you "bought out" time. Why? Because they'll give you unrealistic expectation in other areas. Not only that, the University takes the LARGEST overhead of grants I've ever seen. So, there's greed there too. 7. Admin. Jesus. The ADMIN. Everything is done in duplicate at minimum. Marking? You have to log the results once for those on time, again for the lates, again for the supplemental exam. Research? You have to do ethics twice. Grants? Twice. 8. management. There are have been three heads of school of psychology in my time. The first was amazing. He always worked for us, and we got the sense he was always working with us. The next one was horrendous, basically evil. The newest one is a person who wants so badly to be a buisness man without the business training. From my conversations with my team, he uses words like "revenue raising" and "the work you're paid to" without understanding business decisions from an evidence based perspective. He seems to lack self awareness; one team member told me they talked to him, and he didn't seem to be aware that he had a negative reputation in the staff for a lot of his decisions. Many staff members have left, and he doesn't seem to realise WHY. Now, the first school head DID make some unpopular decisions, but it was well justified and negotiated. This one makes it a personal problem that YOU have rather than anything else. 9. Social groups. The department is split across two buildings on opposite ends of the campus. There are no social groups whatsoever to compensate. There are no department parties, discussion groups, research groups, except in some labs. People are friendly BUT they are overworked and have no incidental contact, meaning you will be alone a lot of the time. 10. Staff attrition. The best people who can leave, do. Four left to the US in 2022, and by my count, at least 3 others left to other places. None left with much warning. They were so sick of it they left suddenly, as much as we liked them. There was no goodbye party for them either. 11. Pay. The staff have been striking for five years for better pay and working conditions, with pensions also at stake. If you came in the past 5 years, and had a yearly increase as part of your contract, you went backwards in pay due to inflation. In real terms, you have lost 17% of your salary, with a tax increase of 1% on top of that. But the university has the money. They made over a billion during the pandemic as profit, and yet, the staff didn't see that money. Finally, Birmingham itself is a depressing city too. It is a city in desperate need of revitalisation. It's close to London but the trains are so expensive. Don't go here. If you can go elsewhere, go.

review_title: No one cares, no progression - good place if you are not ambitious
pros:
*Freedom - No one cares what you are doing aside from project sponsors. You can literally never come in and no one will notice.
*The admin, support and occasional academic are nice (lots of egos and in-fighting at the top though and there is a big disconnect between research/support/admin staff and upper management).
*Diverse community of people at the lower level. However, could certainly be more diverse at the academic level - they continue to hire mostly men even though they pretend to care about gender diversity.
cons:
*Pay is poor despite contracts being fixed-term.
*Finance dept. is painfully slow, delaying projects for weeks.
*Not a research institution - mainly doing engineering projects for SME's and large companies, not science.
*Key school facilities constantly broken for extended periods.
*Care more about giving students good grade than actually teaching students knowledge they can take forward into their future career.
*No planned route to lectureship, even if you get a fellowship or bring in your own funding they offer no pathway towards taking that next step (only hire outside the Dept.).
*Manipulate you into doing teaching and admin tasks that won't get you into a lectureship (basically jobs that academics don't want to do) - just focus on papers if you want to progress into a lecturer.

review_title: Fantastic students, some good colleagues, dire management
pros:
I worked with a very good team, and really enjoyed my (postgraduate) students. Salary was to scale.
Plenty of opportunities to get involved in research.
cons:
However, the university is managed from the centre and had a dire VC (he's still there) on a huge salary. The centre consistently worked against staff and students, and was highly politically motivated. For me, the final straw was when a group of unqualified Tory cronies were catapulted into our department and given a huge budget for politically motivated research. It was the worst combination of "jobs for the boys" coupled with right-wing think-tank-style "research" I've seen yet in my academic career.
Promotion from one band to the next is also notoriously difficult at Birmingham (unless, it seems, you have mates in Whitehall and the VC's mansion...)
There were also major administrative problems in my department, but this could be very different elsewhere in the university.

review_title: Best Railway Research department in Europe
job_title: PhD Student/Teaching Assistant in Birmingham, England
pros:
I am an Engineering PhD Researcher at the Railway Research centre of the University of Birmingham. 

Birmingham is the best research centre in the UK for railway research, with the added benefit of it being in Britain's second largest city and in an industrial area. This gives the University a considerable advantage since there are many other Multi-national corporations/Small businesses in the area to work with. 

The Research centre focuses heavily on industrial innovation and thus gets a lot of funding from the industry apart from the academic research body.

Training opportunities in BCRRE are great and there is funding available to do various courses and participate in conferences.

Has a really good global reputation and excellent infrastructure. Beautiful and smart modern buildings and green spaces are being constructed. There are many groups to get involved in. One of the most modern Health and fitness centres among any university in the UK. 

New UK Rail Research and Innovation Network building with many new opportunities coming up. 

Academic teaching/support jobs pay well and add to your salary.
cons:
Lower pay than in the industry

The Railway Research centre is currently focussing more on expansion and business development and the number of staff is disproportionate for the amount to work needed to be done. More staff need to be recruited

review_title: superb supervisor but below average adminstration system
pros: supervisors are given a lot of autonomy, and in my department, that translated into an exceptional work environment including daily group lunches, flexible work options, and a genuine expression of concern for my wellbeing in and out of the workplace
cons:
-it took over 2 months to receive my first paycheck because the central administration kept making mistakes in processing my paperwork
-focused on unnecessary rules (I know they are unnecessary because I now have a masters in human resources) that undermined the amazing work environment created by my supervisor
-bottom line, my supervisor had a vision of how work environment and respect can lead to better results while the central administration was entrenched in the past focus on rules and regulations which end up stifling profits and progress

pros:
A very prestigious campus with lots to offer in terms of holiday entitlement, awards ceremonies such as the Oscar's where you can be nominated for numerous awards, get to know students and build a rapport with regular customers and work with some really dedicated members of staff who can make your day enjoyable. 

There are also alot of events around campus such as comedy nights and places to visit such as the Lapworth museum and Barber institute of fine arts.

If you are seen to be hard working, you will be noticed and will only benefit through progression or some forms of reward.
cons:
Can be an extremely stressful environment and when working in a large workforce, you find there can be alot of animosity that creates an atmosphere and can make working days extremely unbareable. 

You have to be willingly very flexible to meet the demands of the business, this can interfere with your personal life if you have made plans outside of work or have commitments.

Working hours can be till very late and need to be willing to sacrifice a lot of weekends.

pros: Really good university and environment to work in. With huge potential and loads of great scientists and fresh minds. Cooperation between staff is usually really good and there are loads of opportunities of collaborations and high end science. Research facilities throughout the university is very good and it is rarely needed to search a different institution for sample analysis.
cons: Lately investments are mainly focused in projects aimed to attract students such as a new library, sports center etc and not in more high caliber staff and equipment, which results in a drop in rankings due to poorer student/staff ratio. At the same time, instrument repair takes time since the university is reluctant to pay even in cases they know what the problem is and the problems arising. As a result instrument waiting time increases and data production takes far longer than normal.

review_title: Wouldn’t recommend but depends on the job
job_title: Within External Relations in Birmingham, England
pros: Benefits are good but it means people stay too long and far too many incompetent people on cushy salaries.
cons: Manager had no management skills and believed managing was delegating everything to their team of one (myself) as they were too incompetent to do any of it. Senior Managers knew this and allowed it because of favouritism and laziness. Far too many people think getting ahead is not working and doing your job well but getting in front of the directors and senior managers. My experience was that many had been in Higher Education since Uni and had not been in the private sector, a lot of unprofessional and immature behaviour as a result.

pros: A career in research is something you either choose to do from the onset or retire to.  The research at Birmingham is a comfortable career focussed on pioneering work and cutting edge results.
cons: As with any academic career, expect to have to spend a lot of time teaching, even those that don't want to learn!  University level research is not a career that is financially rewarding in any real way.

review_title: Flexible working is good, lack of community and colleagues is bad
pros: Very flexible terms allow people to live away, and come in only for their lectures
cons: Birmingham is a boring city, in many ways, and so few people live there and i rarely see my colleagues. There is no social aspect to work. People do not seem particularly ambitious. The university support functions are poor - there is often one administrator  for 100s of staff, and you can wait a long time for finance to process things.

job_title: Graduate Teaching Assistant in Edgbaston, England
pros: It offers good experience and a chance to build your CV. The new undergraduate students are always fun to interact with, both in and out of class. It's also a recognizable 'brand' in global education.
cons: The POLSIS Department's leadership leaves a lot to be desired. They expect you to cover all their teaching, to the detriment of your own PhD. They regularly expect you to exceed your allotted teaching hours. They also do NOTHING to help PhDs find careers after completion. They take your tuition, recycle the same approaches, then move on to the next cohort. This might be a reflection of wider UK higher education however.

review_title: What a great place to work!
pros:
- As a student at the University of Birmingham, it is very easy to get a part-time job across campus with excellent pay.
- Wonderful culture with people who really care about you.
- Flexible: could come in a bit early to finish a bit early!
cons: - Students are only allowed to work 15 hours per week - of course this is to ensure your studies are a priority, but my schedule changed from one week to the next meaning at times I was perfectly capable of doing more than 15 hours per week, yet this was not allowed.

review_title: Very rewarding working together with so many great peopls.
pros: People from various backgrounds interact strongly with each other trying to produce high quality work. In addition the university is placed within a beautiful campus which lends itself easily for great lunch breaks.
cons: There are some instances where you cannot understand how certain parts of the management get it wrong so badly. It sometimes feels like an industry not like a not-for-profit organisation.

pros:
Friendly people, wanting to do their best and improve things.
Good benefits, good extra holidays (extra 7 each year full-time).
If you are a parent, on-site and near site holiday clubs for children.
New sports centre will be excellent.
Good ethics.
cons:
Slow to change.
Non-existent talent management.
Difficult to get on if you don't tick 10/10 boxes on a person spec - inability to see ability and potential rather than just fitting a complete job description.
Active holding back of people's development by some management.
Not direct experience but anecdotally VC and some senior management very difficult to work for.

review_title: Overall good location, depending your previous experience
pros:
Relaxed environment supportive staff. Amazing campus with many facilities. Good labs 
You can work from home, as the department will give you a laptop. Good international mix of people.
cons: Sometimes, groups of international students will create a micro group and talk in their own language as it is easier not to speak in English. That results into same country collaborations which is a negative experience for people that have experienced that kind of discrimination. Sometimes there are double standards and you might lose a new position due to personal relations, even if you are more qualified.

review_title: Good employer but I've reached my maximum potential in the role.

cons:
Rollercoaster - Very slow to change or changes rushed once agreed by management.

review_title: A great place to work in the most part although, support for staff is not their when needed.
pros: A great place to do research and collaborate with other scientists.
cons: University as a whole is not good at looking after or retaining their staff or postgraduate students. Little or no support with issues such as bullying mental health issues . All efforts are focused on attracting new students and staff with specific backgrounds to boost ratings and image. Current staff in my department don't even have anywhere to eat lunch.

review_title: Excellent scientific community but poor supportive functions
pros: Good experiences within the scientific community. Fruitful collaborations and partnerships are possible. Facilities are ok/good and most are accessible. Technical core facilities are available with excellent skilled personal. Very good opportunities to learn more and broaden scientific knowledge and skills!
cons: Supportive functions such as HR, payrol, finance etc are disorganized and communicate poorly, both to employees as well as to each other. Incompetent personal. This results in serious delays, misunderstandings and lots of frustration. Paperwork fiasco!

pros:

High level non-academic roles are many, but in some cases they are pretty ineffective.

Funding for small things at departmental level is very poor, so you have to pay your own expenses more often than not.

There is nowhere near enough parking for the number of staff on site.

pros: Academic line managers were incredibly supportive and approachable. Provided plenty of opportunity for personal and professional development through courses and lectures. Friendly work environment.

cons: Biosciences building a bit dated but situated in the centre of campus. Because the university is located close to hospital the traffic is awful getting to and from work. Also parking is a major issue however the train station is very close and convenient.

review_title: British universities are too much companies and too little university
job_title: PhD Graduate Student in Birmingham, England
pros: Cutting edge laboratories, nice campus, libraries, all kinds of facilities
cons: British education is lower quality with respect to the other European countries. The student is so well taken care of that they feel entitled to pass even when they should be failed, just because the fees are high, even in public universities

pros: This is a brilliant university with many leading academics. It is set in beautiful grounds and not too far away from the centre of Birmingham which has everything you could possibly need

job_title: Central Services Technician in Birmingham, England
pros: working at a campus which was beautiful in summer, a real outdoor feeling of freedom.  Multicultured environment.
cons: Where to begin, the interview seems technical, the job role was pathetic for your career at best. Doing the cleanup work for most of the building, which seems fine until you realise it's mainly waste from Biological experiments, e.g. TB, HIV etc, sterilised in 95% of the time an overpacked autoclave (so not sure how it can be 100% sterilised if there is no airflow). Most of us were elderly, carrying heavy loads around the building, working in hot temps - autoclaves were at 121c, Carry and sort clean out heavy hot metal cans full of waste, where we had to stand over them and breath in the "sterilised fumes" - Disgusting and so dangerous. Constant standing on some activities for long periods, repetitive tasks to the point where you would feel sore - no one from management really cared when anyone brought up the concerning work, workload or demeaning behaviour of a manager who made it feel like you weren't doing enough.  After a full day of grafting, the last 30 mins is when the manager would come and "help you out" so you do more, most days I went home and felt like not going back and went straight to bed due to back pain. Supervisor - wow, what a joke, left you to it, never around, was meant to be working with you but always on jollies, always pretending to be somewhere, doing something, could never be found and never gets caught - no one from management believes you when you express this. Colleagues are friendly and even great! Accept one, who doesn't look like she'll leave any time soon, bossy and takes all the credit for everything - very political and confrontational, made work a nightmare for some of the other colleagues. Overall - I would never recommend working as a Central Services technician in the Bioscience building for Birmingham University.

pros: Wonderful atmosphere, excellent work-ethic. Friendly colleagues, and approachable management among the administration teams. cons: I experienced no negative issues whilst working in the University.
